prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: N2H+ 3-2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Map of the N2H+ J= 3-2 line emission

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The goal of the proposal is mapping the N2H+ 3-2 line, placed in baseband 1 at 279.5GHz. The linewidth is expected to be 3km/s so that we selected a spectral resolution of 0.26km/s and computed the sensitivity over a 0.5km/s velocity bin, so that we will capable to study the kinematics in the brightest spots.

We will need 0.7" to identify structures where the line emission is enhanced, in order to fullfill the goal of the proposal, based on the predictions of the ionisation from the various models listed in the proposal Table 1. The observations in our hands (IRAM-30mt and Herschel-HIF single-dish, plus the interferometric observations at PdBI and NMA -Ceccarelli et al. 2014; Lopez-Sepulcre et al. 2013; Shimajiri et al. 2008-) suggest that the N2H+ line emission will be extended over a 18"x18" area. The proposal goal is to map the whole emitting area and disentangle its structures, namely to trace the gradients and also to identify the most intense sources.

Line observations: we request a rms of 60mJy over 0.5km/s velocity bin, based on the single-dish observations, IRAM-30m and Herschel-HIFI, of the N2H+ lines with Jup=1 to Jup=9. Specifically, the 3-2 line intensity is predicted to be 0.3Jy assuming that the single-dish signal is spread over a 18"x18" area, which is a conservative assumption. For the sensitivity calculation we used a bandwidth of 0.5km/s, as the linewidth is about 3km/s. Continuum observations: the continuum intensity is estimated from PdBI observations at 145GHz (Lopez-Sepulcre et al. 2013, A&A 556, 62.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H13CO+ 3-2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Map of the H13CO+ J= 3-2 line emission

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The goal of the proposal is mapping the H13CO+ 3-2 line, placed in baseband 1 at 260.2GHz. The linewidth is expected around 3km/s so that we selected a spectral resolution of 0.27km/s and computed the sensitivity over a 0.5km/s velocity bin, so that we will capable to study the kinematics in the brightest spots.

We will need 0.7" to identify structures where the line emission is enhanced, in order to fullfill the goal of the proposal, based on the predictions of the ionisation from the various models listed in the proposal Table 1. The observations in our hands (IRAM-30mt and Herschel-HIF single-dish, plus the interferometric observations at PdB and NMA -Ceccarelli et al. 2014; Lopez-Sepulcre et al. 2013; Shimajiri et al. 2008-) suggest that the H13CO+ line emission will be extended over a 18"x18" area. The proposal goal is to map the whole emitting area and disentangle its structures, namely to trace the gradients and also to identify the most intense sources.

Line observations: we request a rms of 12mJy over 0.5km/s velocity bin, based on the single-dish observations, IRAM-30m and Herschel-HIFI, of the H13CO+ lines with Jup=1 to Jup=9. Specifically, the 3-2 line intensity is predicted to be 0.06Jy assuming that the single-dish signal is spread over a 18"x18" area, which is a conservative assumption. For the sensitivity calculation we used a bandwidth of 0.5km/s, as the linewidth is about 3km/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCO+ 3-2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Map of the HCO+ J= 3-2 line emission

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The goal of the proposal is mapping the HCO+ 3-2 line, placed in baseband 1 at 267.6GHz. The linewidth is expected around 3km/s so that we selected a spectral resolution of 0.137km/s and computed the sensitivity over a 0.5km/s velocity bin, so that we will capable to study the kinematics in the brightest spots.

We will need 0.7" to identify structures where the line emission is enhanced, in order to fullfill the goal of the proposal, based on the predictions of the ionisation from the various models listed in the proposal Table 1. The observations in our hands (IRAM-30mt and Herschel-HIF single-dish, plus the interferometric observations at PdB and NMA -Ceccarelli et al. 2014; Lopez-Sepulcre et al. 2013; Shimajiri et al. 2008-) suggest that the HCO+ line emission will be extended over a 18"x18" area. The proposal goal is to map the whole emitting area and disentangle its structures, namely to trace the gradients and also to identify the most intense sources.

Line observations: we request a rms of 60mJy over a 0.5km/s velocity bin, based on the single-dish observations, IRAM-30m and Herschel-HIFI, of the HCO+ lines with Jup=1 to Jup=9. Specifically, the 3-2 line intensity is predicted to be 0.3Jy assuming that the single-dish signal is spread over a 18"x18" area, which is a conservative assumption. For the sensitivity calculation we used a bandwidth of 0.5km/s, as the linewidth is about 3km/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Map of N2H+ 5-4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Map of the N2H+ J= 5-4 line emission

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The goal of the proposal is mapping the N2H+ 5-4 line, placed in baseband 1 at 465.8GHz. The linewidth is expected around 3km/s so that we selected a spectral resolution of 0.156km/s and computed the sensitivity over a 0.5km/s velocity bin, so that we will capable to study the kinematics in the brightest spots.

We will need 0.7" to identify structures where the line emission is enhanced, in order to fullfill the goal of the proposal, based on the predictions of the ionisation from the various models listed in the proposal Table 1. The observations in our hands (IRAM-30mt and Herschel-HIFI single-dish -Ceccarelli et al. 2014) suggest that the N2H+ 5-4 line emission will be extended over a 18"x18" area. The proposal goal is to map the whole emitting area and disentangle its structures, namely to trace the gradients and also to identify the most intense sources.

Line observations: we request a rms of 300mJy over 0.5km/s velocity bin, based on the single-dish observations, Herschel-HIFI, of the N2H+ 6-5 line. Specifically, the 6-5 line intensity is predicted to be 1Jy assuming that the single-dish signal is spread over a 18"x18" area, which is a conservative assumption. For the sensitivity calculation we used a bandwidth of 0.5km/s, as the linewidth is about 3km/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The young solar system was not a quiescent environment that calmly formed planets. It is now known that it was also bathed in high-energy particles during this period. A main line of evidence for this is the large abundance of decay products of the short-lived radionuclide 10Be in meteorites, which implies that large fluencies of particles with energies >10MeV did reach meteoritic material before it was incorporated into parent bodies. The source of these particles has been a mystery for more than 15 years. New Herschel observations might have, finally, provided us with a way to probe the existence of such particles in young star-forming regions. Observations towards a protostar (or cluster of protostars), OMC-2 FIR4, of two molecular ions, HCO+ and N2H+, appear to probe the presence of one or more sources of >10MeV particles inside the cloud. We propose to obtain high resolution maps of the two ions in the OMC2-FIR4 cloud in order to directly locate these sources and, consequently, understand their nature. Ultimately, this will provide us with a new set of constraints to the theories of the Solar System early phases.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astronomical Institute Anton Pannekoek, University of Amsterdam
Laboratoire Univers et Particules de Montpellier, Universite Montpellier II
Graduate School of Science, The University of Tokyo
Institut de Recherche en Astrophysique et Planetologie
